properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A vigorous cold front will move across the province of Quebec today. As it passes, flurries at times heavy could affect several regions of Southern Quebec. This snow combined with strong winds could significantly reduce local visibilities. Temperatures behind this front will drop rapidly. Adjust your driving to changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-19T23:04:45-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southerly 100 km/h. Locations: eastern Newfoundland. Time span: continuing until early this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-20T00:59:45-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible beginning tonight. With the arrival of cold northwesterly winds, snow squalls are forecast to develop over Lake Huron and Georgian Bay. As winds shift this evening, these snow squalls are expected to move over the area and then continue into tonight. Local snowfall amounts in the 10 to 15 cm range will be possible by Thursday morning. An additional 2 to 4 cm will be possible Thursday as the squalls weaken. Visibilities will likely be reduced at times in heavy snow and blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-20T12:17:50-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm. Locations: Burgeo and vicinity. Time span: continuing until this afternoon. Remarks: Rain, at times heavy will taper off later this afternoon. Snow in still possible inland near noon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-19T22:59:09-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain, and strong southerly winds expected today. Total snowfall amounts: 5 to 10 cm. Total rainfall amounts: 5 to 10 mm, except up to 15 mm along the southern shore. Maximum wind gusts: southerly generally between 60 to 80 km/h except 100 along parts of the coast. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Strong southerly winds will accompany the snow causing a few hours of poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow over all areas near noon. The snow will change through ice pellets to rain early in the afternoon over all areas. The rain and mild temperatures are likely to cause localized flooding and water pooling on roads. The public should prepare for poor travel conditions throughout the day today. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-20T04:59:51-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls this afternoon and tonight. The flurries will intensify into snow squalls this afternoon. These snow squalls will shift northward and then remain over the area through tonight. Additional flurries and local snow squalls will be possible Thursday. Snowfall amounts in the 10 to 15 cm range can be expected by Thursday morning. Visibilities will be reduced at times in heavy snow and blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values close to minus 40 expected tonight and Thursday morning. Under clear skies and moderate winds temperatures are forecast to reach near minus 30 degrees celsius tonight and Thursday morning with wind chill values close to minus 40. Temperatures are expected to rise by midday Thursday bringing an end to the extreme cold. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Dangerous wind chills of -50 to -55 will develop in Iqaluit tonight as temperatures dip to a low near -36C and northwest winds strengthen to 30 km/h. Warning level wind chills will end on Thursday morning as temperatures climb towards -30C, but northwest winds of 40 gusting 60 km/h will maintain wind chills of -45 to -50 through the day. Dangerous wind chills below -50 will likely redevelop on Thursday evening as temperatures begin to fall again. Cold conditions will continue through the weekend with wind chills generally in the -40 to -50 range. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-20T12:29:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-19T20:30:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3499029846.2020
Area: Iqaluit

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A developing low pressure system over the Arctic mainland coast has brought strong gusty easterly winds and blizzard conditions to Ulukhaktok. The winds will ease late Thursday morning and blizzard conditions should end near noon. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VERNON (February 18, 2020 - Vernon) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Vernon because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-20T00:15:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-02-19T11:37:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3055963853.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times continues. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-20T02:59:22-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Coldest wind chills: near -46. Locations: western Labrador. Time span: overnight tonight and Thursday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
